title: 105_hr3568
content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements if not imposed on medical and surgical benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from negotiating separate reimbursement rates and managing benefits through pre-admission screening. It does not require specific mental health benefits or prevent plans from applying subsection (a) for preventive care. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 prohibit group health plans from negotiating separate reimbursement rates and managing benefits through pre-admission screening. The amendments define treatment limits as restrictions on the frequency and scope of treatment, and financial limits as copayments, deductibles, and other charges imposed on covered individuals. Amendments also eliminate cost exemptions and sunset provisions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to ensure parity in the application of treatment limitations and financial requirements for mental health benefits in group health plans. Treatment limitations and financial requirements for mental health benefits should be comparable to those for medical and surgical benefits in similar settings. Group health plans are not prohibited from negotiating separate reimbursement rates or managing benefit provision. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to ensure parity in treatment limitations and financial requirements for mental health benefits in group health plans. Treatment limits refer to restrictions on treatment frequency, visits, or duration, excluding those based solely on medical necessity. Financial requirements are also defined in the context of mental health benefits. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to ensure parity in treatment limitations and financial requirements for mental health benefits in group health plans. This includes eliminating cost exemptions, sunset provisions, and making clerical amendments. Additionally, the application to individual health insurance is addressed in the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 2752 addresses parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits in group health plans. The provisions of section 2705 apply to individual market health insurance coverage in the same way as group health plan coverage. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment date. The provisions of section 2705 apply to individual market health insurance coverage starting on or after July 1, 1999. Any plan amendments made to conform to new requirements shall not terminate collective bargaining agreements. Effective on the date of enactment of this Act, section 104(1) of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 is amended to include provisions from other relevant acts. SEC. 3. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY BENEFITS. This section amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to ensure that benefits for substance abuse and chemical dependency treatment are subject to the same limits as mental health benefits. It also amends the Public Health Service Act to include similar provisions. The text chunk discusses the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits, ensuring parity with mental health benefits under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 9813 ensures parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits, while SEC. 2753 focuses on parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits under the Public Health Service Act. The provisions of section 2752 apply to benefits for substance abuse or chemical dependency treatment, similar to mental health benefits. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to individual health insurance coverage in the market on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements.
